bestBHT.bht: During the last week of His life, Jesus spent His days teaching in the temple, openly preaching the Gospel to the people. At night, He would retreat to the Mount of Olives, likely to pray for Himself and His disciples, as His time with them was growing short. This pattern of teaching in the temple during the day and lodging on the Mount of Olives at night was His constant method each day of that fateful week. While Matthew and Mark mention Bethany as His place of lodging, Luke includes the Mount of Olives as part of this abode.

Philip Schaff: Luke 21:37. Every day. Lit., ‘the days,’ definite days of that week of His passion.
Luke makes no mention of Bethany, where, according to Matthew and Mark, our Lord spent the nights of Sunday and Monday.
Bethany was probably the place, and Olivet is here mentioned as including it.
Archibald T. Robertson: Every day (τας ημερας). During the days, accusative of extent of time.
Every night (τας νυκτας). "During the nights," accusative of extent of time.
Lodged (ηυλιζετο). Imperfect middle, was lodging, αυλιζομα from αυλη (court).
John Gill: His constant method every day... was to go up to the temple, and there openly and freely preach the Gospel to the people."
At night he went out... and abode in the mount that is called the Mount of Olives."
Very likely to pray, both for himself and for his disciples, his time with them being short.
John Wesley: In the day time, he was teaching in the temple.
It does not therefore by any means imply, that he came any more after this into the temple.
But it is not said, he was this day in the temple, and next morning the people came.

bhtAttempts.bht: During the last week of His life, Jesus spent His days teaching in the temple, openly preaching the Gospel to the people. At night, He would retreat to the Mount of Olives, likely to pray for Himself and His disciples, as His time with them was growing short. This pattern of teaching in the temple during the day and lodging on the Mount of Olives at night was His constant method each day of that fateful week. While Matthew and Mark mention Bethany as His place of lodging, Luke includes the Mount of Olives as part of this abode.

During the days of His last week, Jesus would teach openly in the temple, proclaiming the Gospel to the people. At night, He would retreat to the Mount of Olives, most likely to pray for Himself and His disciples. This was His regular routine, with each day filled with teaching in the temple and lodging on the Mount of Olives. While Matthew and Mark mention Bethany as His lodging place, Luke includes the Mount of Olives in this account.

During His last week, Jesus would spend His days teaching in the temple, openly preaching the Gospel to the people. He would then go to the Mount of Olives to lodge at night, most likely to pray for Himself and His disciples. This routine continued throughout the week, with each day dedicated to teaching in the temple and finding refuge on the Mount of Olives. While some accounts mention Bethany as His lodging place, Luke includes the Mount of Olives in this description.

During His final days, Jesus would spend His time teaching in the temple, openly proclaiming the Gospel to the people. At night, He would retreat to the Mount of Olives, likely for prayer and reflection. This was His regular routine throughout the week, with each day dedicated to teaching in the temple and finding solace on the Mount of Olives. Though other accounts mention Bethany as His place of lodging, Luke includes the Mount of Olives in this depiction.

During the days of His last week, Jesus would teach openly in the temple, preaching the Gospel to the people. At night, He would retreat to the Mount of Olives, most likely to pray for Himself and His disciples. This was His constant method every day, with each day filled with teaching in the temple and lodging on the Mount of Olives. While some accounts mention Bethany as His place of lodging, Luke includes the Mount of Olives in this description, suggesting that it encompassed Bethany as well.
